Fig. 1 Representative N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of (a) nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts having various Mg/V molar ratios and (b) xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts with different VxOy contents. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Representative (a, b) small-angle and (c, d) wide-angle (at 25 ºC) XRD patterns of the nMgO-VKIT-6 and xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Representative TEM images of (a) VKIT-6, (b) 0.50MgO-VKIT-6, (c) MgO-KIT-6, and (d) 3V/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts. Inset shows HRTEM images. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Representative H2-TPR profiles of (a) nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts having various Mg/V molar ratios and the (b) xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts with different VxOy contents. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Representative Raman spectra of (a) KIT-6, (b) MgO-KIT-6, (c) 0.50MgO-VKIT-6, and (d) 3V/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Representative (a) V2p, (b) Si2p, and (c) O1s XPS spectra of (i) 0.50MgO-VKIT-6 and (ii) 3 V/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Selectivity in the liquid product and α-alkenes/total alkenes ratio generated from the ODH of OA using (a) nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts and (b) xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Carbon atom distribution in the liquid products derived from the ODH of OA using (a) nMgO-VKIT-6 and (b) xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 The profiles of OA conversion and product selectivity versus contact time obtained from various OA feed rates (Condition: catalyst content ca. 0.25 g, OA feed rate: 0.053, 0.071, 0.089, and 0.107 g min–1 at 450 ⁰C for 2 h time on stream). Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Representative TGA profiles of the spent (a) nMgO-VKIT-6 and (b) xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts (inset is DTG curves) obtained from the ODH of OA after 2 h time on stream at 450 ºC. Fig. 10 Scheme 1 Synthesis of bio-olefins from fatty acids: (a) olefin metathesis, (b) decarbonylative dehydration, and (c) hydrogenation and dehydration. Bangkok 10330 Thailand This study investigated the effect of magnesium oxide (MgO) incorporation into vanadium-KIT-6 (VKIT-6) catalysts and vanadium oxide (VxOy) contents impregnated into MgO-KIT-6 catalysts on the catalytic activity in the oxidative dehydrogenation of oleic acid to generate long-chain bio-olefins ( ≥ C10). The nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts containing different Mg/V molar ratios (n = 0.00–1.50) were prepared by the hydrothermal process, while xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts were synthesized via wet-impregnation method with different vanadium contents (x = 0–9 wt%). The Mg/V molar ratios in the nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts and VxOy contents in the xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts strongly affected the catalytic performance and selectivity to the desired products. Both 0.50MgO-VKIT-6 and 1 V/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts showed the best catalytic activity for the desired products with selectivity to olefins (alkenes + dienes) and aromatics of 52% and 20%, respectively. The high selective production to the desired products was ascribed to the highly dispersed and isolated VxOy species on the catalysts. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords KIT-6 Oleic acid Long-chain olefins Vanadium oxide, Magnesium oxide Oxidative dehydrogenation 1 Introduction To achieve more sustainable chemical industries, commodity chemicals should be increasingly produced from renewable resources. Olefins (alpha- and internal-olefins) are essential and valuable precursors that are widely utilized as co-monomers in the production of polymers, detergents, plasticizers, synthetic lubricants, and drilling fluids [1,2]. At present, olefins are produced almost exclusively from fossil-derived feedstocks through catalytic oligomerization of ethylene, dehydrogenation of n-alkanes obtained from Fischer-Tropsch processing, and the thermal cracking of waxy paraffins [3–5]. However, olefins can also be sustainably and selectively produced from renewable resources [6–8]. With depleting fossil fuel resources and increasing carbon emissions, the utilization of renewable resources for producing olefins is of increasing interest. Fatty acids (FAs) derived from plant oils containing long carbon chains (C12–24) are inexpensive and available for being applied as starting materials. Thus, FAs are attractive as a renewable feedstock for olefin production, particularly long-chain bio-olefins. Several synthetic strategies for bio-olefins production have been described recently [7,9–12]. Olefin metathesis ( Scheme 1a) is a highly selective method for synthesizing olefins via self-metathesis of FAs or cross-metathesis of FAs with ethylene using homogeneous ruthenium-based catalysts [10]. However, only unsaturated FAs are available for the metathesis, and the limitations of homogeneous catalysts still present challenges. Decarbonylative dehydration of FAs (Scheme 1b) has been investigated to produce olefins using transition metals in forms of homogeneous [11,13] and heterogeneous [7,14] catalysts. However, stoichiometric additives, such as acid anhydride and phosphine ligands are required to achieve the best performance and selectivity. Alternatively, olefins could be synthesized via two-step catalytic hydrogenation of FAs into fatty alcohol, followed by dehydration (Scheme 1c) [12,15]. Oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) is a convenient and accessible method for producing olefins from n-alkanes. It is thermodynamically favorable at low reaction temperatures and usually inhibits the formation of coke and cracking of smaller hydrocarbons (HCs) [16]. Therefore, ODH represents a potential alternative method to non-ODH for the production of olefins. However, the over-oxidation of the obtained olefins to carbon monoxide (CO) and carbon dioxide (CO2) always limits the olefin yield, particularly at a high conversion level. As a result, numerous studies have reported on the ODH of alkanes to produce olefins. For example, the ODH of light alkanes generated several alkenes (ethylene, propylene, and butene) with a selectivity in the range of 10–70% over vanadium oxides-based catalysts [16–18]. Moreover, the synthesis of medium-chain olefins (C6–12) via the ODH of long-chain alkanes (C6 - 12) has also been reported [19–21]. Although the ODH process of alkanes has been explored to create a wide range of olefin chain lengths, from short-chain (C2–4) to medium-chain (C6–12), the production of long-chain olefins has not been reported for the ODH of FAs. The merits of the ODH process to produce olefins from alkanes are a driving force behind the development of bio-olefins from the ODH of FAs. Previous work demonstrated the conversion of oleic acid (OA) to long-chain bio-olefins via ODH over vanadium-incorporated KIT-6 catalysts (nV-KIT-6) prepared by a direct hydrothermal process [22]. The performance of nV-KIT-6 catalysts was strongly related to the nature of the vanadium oxide (VxOy) phase. Isolated VxOy species with a low agglomeration or coordination structure favored the selectivity to olefins and dienes, whereas polymeric VxOy species and V2O5 crystallines promoted the formation of oxygenated compounds. Although the prepared catalysts exhibited a 76% OA conversion level and 36% selectivity towards bio-olefins (C7 - 17), the formation of oxygenated compounds remained high (18% selectivity), especially at higher VxOy contents due to the existence of polymeric VxOy species and V2O5 crystallines. Previous studies have reported that vanadium-magnesium oxide (VMgO) catalysts were considered as the most active and selective catalysts for the ODH of long-chain alkanes due to their poor tendency to form oxygenates and cracking products [21,23]. In the VMgO catalyst, the MgO was likely to interact intensively with the vanadium, resulting in a high vanadium dispersion on the support. Furthermore, the incorporation of vanadium into MgO inhibited the formation of V2O5 crystallines containing VO bonds, which are believed to promote the formation of oxygenates and combustion products [24,25]. On the other hand, the three-dimensional mesoporous silica KIT-6 was effective for the dispersion and stability of VxOy species due to its uniform channels and large porosities. Therefore, the combination of MgO with vanadium on the mesoporous silica KIT-6 is expected to form an efficient catalyst for the selective ODH of OA, which is the most common FA found in the plant oils. This research aimed to compare two kinds of VMgO/KIT-6 catalysts for producing long-chain bio-olefins via the ODH of OA. These catalysts were prepared by (i) direct hydrothermal and (ii) impregnation methods. For the direct hydrothermal method, vanadium was incorporated with MgO and the KIT-6 framework in a one-pot synthesis using various molar ratios of Mg/V (named as nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts, where the Mg/V molar ratio (n) was in the range of 0.00–1.50). In contrast, in the impregnation method, the different vanadium contents were post-loaded on the MgO-KIT-6 framework (coded as xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts, where x is the vanadium content in the range of 0–9 wt% based on the amount of catalyst). The properties of the prepared catalysts were characterized by nitrogen (N2)-adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), ammonia-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), hydrogen-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Their catalytic performance for the ODH of OA was conducted in a fixed-bed reactor under atmospheric pressure to produce the long-chain bio-olefins. The effects of the Mg/V molar ratios in the nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts and the vanadium contents in the xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts on the degrees of OA conversion and selectivity to olefins in the obtained liquid product were examined. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The MgO-VKIT-6 catalysts were prepared by a modified one-pot hydrothermal method [22]. Typically, Pluronic P123 (7.5 g) (EO20PO70EO20; Mw = 5800, Sigma-Aldrich) was completely dissolved in a mixture of deionized water (174 g) and concentrated hydrochloric acid (36 wt%, 11.8 mL, Duksan). An appropriate amount of ammonia metavanadate (NH4VO3; 99%, Ajax Finechem) and magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg(NO3)2.6 H2O; 99%, Aldrich), based on the given Mg(NO3)2.6 H2O/NH4VO3 (Mg/V) molar ratios, were dissolved in deionized (DI) water (93 g) and added into the Pluronic P123 acidic solution and vigorously stirred for 4 h at 35 °C. Thereafter, n-butanol (7.39 g, 99%, RCI Labscan) was added into the mixture under agitation at 35 °C for 1 h, followed by slowly dripping 15.85 g tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS; 98%, Aldrich) into the mixture and continuously stirring at 35 °C for 24 h. The NH4VO3/TEOS molar ratio at V/Si of 0.05 was selected as the optimum ratio based on a previous study [22]. The obtained gel was aged in the Teflon cylinder placed in a stainless steel at 100 °C for 24 h under a static hydrothermal condition. After precipitation, the solid product was filtered, washed several times with DI water, and dried at 60 ºC for 16 h. The calcination of catalysts was then performed at 550 ºC using a ramping rate of 1 °C min–1 for 6 h. The resulted catalysts were designated as nMgO-VKIT-6, where n was the Mg/V molar ratio (0.00–1.50). The MgO-KIT-6 (Mg/Si molar ratio = 0.05) was synthesized under the same conditions without the NH4VO3 addition. The loading of VxOy was subsequently impregnated onto MgO-KIT-6 support with the NH4VO3 aqueous solution at the given concentrations. Briefly, the required amount of NH4VO3 was completely dissolved in DI water (20 mL) at 60 °C. Then, MgO-KIT-6 (2.0 g) was added into the NH4VO3 solution under stirring at 60 °C for 2 h. The resultant mixture was then evaporated under vacuum at 60 °C and dried at 110 °C for 16 h. Finally, the obtained solid product was ground and calcined in air at 550 °C with a heating rated of 1 °C min–1 for 5 h. The calcined catalysts were named as xV/MgO-KIT-6, where x was the vanadium loading level (0–9 wt%) based on the catalyst contents. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The XRD patterns of all catalysts was analyzed by a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (Switzerland) using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å, 40 kV, 20 mA) at room temperature. The TEM images were visualized on a JEOL, JEM-1400 F (Japan) operated at 80 kV, while N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 apparatus at –196 °C. The samples were degassed under vacuum at 300 °C for 90 min before analysis. The specific surface area calculated from the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method (SBET) was reported. The pore size distribution and pore volume were recorded from the absorption branch of the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms following the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The FT-Raman spectra were recorded on a Perkin Elmer Spectrum GX. A visible excitation wavelength of 532 nm was used by the Nd–YAG laser with a resolution of 4 cm–1. The XPS was recorded on a Kratos Axis ultra DLD (Japan) spectrometer with an Al Kα X-ray diffraction source (hv= 1486.6 eV). The binding energy (BE) respected to the C1s signal at 284.6 eV was used as the reference. The NH3-TPD and H2-TPR analyses were performed on a Belcat-Basic Chemisorption analyzer (BELCAT II, Japan) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Attenuated total reflectance-Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR) of the studied catalysts was carried out using a Perkin Elmer Spectrum 100 FTIR (USA) spectrometer in the spectra range of 600–4000 cm–1 with a resolution of 4 cm–1 for 64 scans. The amount of carbon deposited on the catalysts was measured on a TGA 8000 Perkin Elmer (USA) thermogravimetric analyzer in the temperature range of 30–800 °C at a heating rate of 10 ⁰C min–1 under an air atmosphere with a gas flow of 50 mL min–1. 2.3 Catalytic ODH and product analysis The catalytic ODH of OA was operated in a fixed-bed downflow reactor under atmospheric pressure at 450 ºC. In a typical run, catalyst (0.25 g) was loaded between two layers of quartz wool, and glass beads (2.0 g) were placed on the top of the catalyst layer in the stainless-steel reactor tube (15.75 mm diameter; 140 mm length), as previously described [22]. Pristine OA (Sigma-Aldrich) was introduced into the reactor using a high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) pump at a flow rate of 0.089 g min–1 (weight hourly space velocity = 21 h–1) to totally convert the OA as the gas phase before entering to the catalyst bed. Oxygen (O2; 99.99% as an oxidant) and N2 (99.99% as a make-up gas) were delivered into the reactor by two separated electronic mass flow controllers to keep a total flow rate of 100 mL min–1 (gas hourly space velocity [GHSV] = 400 [mL/(min g-cat)]). The OA/O2 molar ratio and O2/N2 volume ratio were maintained at 0.14 and 1.0, respectively. An ice-water bath condenser at ca. 2 °C was used for trapping the condensable gaseous products consisting of water, liquid products, and unreacted OA. The incondensable gaseous products were collected using a gasbag. To evaluate the role of the catalyst, a blank experiment was also conducted under the identical experimental conditions at 450 °C using a glass bead-pack reactor. The result showed that the non-catalytic ODH process provided the negligible OA conversion level (~1%), mainly COx production. All catalytic data reported were obtained during the first 2 h of time on stream (except for the long-term stability tests). All data points were obtained in duplicate. The carbon balance obtained from the ODH of OA was in the range of 90–100%. The standard gas was used in this assay 4.99 mol methane (CH4), 5.01 mol ethane (C2H6), 5.03 mol ethylene (C2H2), 4.99 mol propane (C3H8), 5.0 mol propylene (C3H6), 5.08 mol propadiene (C3H4), 5.02 mol n-butane (n-C4H10), 5.0 mol iso-butane (i-C4H10), 5.03 mol 1-butene (C4H8), and 5.01 mol trans-2-butene (trans-2-C4H8) balance in N2. The produced gases were examined using offline gas chromatography GC (Shimadzu GC-14B, Japan) connected to TCD, fitted with a Unibead C packed column (3 mm diameter; 2 m length), and a flame ionization detector (FID), fitted with a Hayesep Q packed column (0.25 mm diameter; 2 m length; 0.25 µm film thickness). The analysis was performed in the spitless mode using helium (He) as a carrier gas (flow rate = 20 mL min–1). The temperature of oven was programmed at 50 °C for 5 min, then increased to 200 °C at 5 °C min–1 and kept at this temperature for 15 min. The representative of the GC-FID chromatogram of the gas phase product was shown in Fig. S1. The quantity of unreacted OA in the liquid products was determined using a GC-FID (Agilent, USA) with an HP-5 column (0.32 mm diameter; 30 m length; 0.25 µm film thickness). The degree of OA conversion was determined from the calibration coefficient calculated by analyzing different OA concentrations. The chemical compositions in the liquid products were identified by GC-mass spectrometry (MS; GCMS-QP2020 NX, Shimadzu, Japan) connected with a Nexis GC-2030 gas chromatograph and a DB-5 column (0.25 mm diameter; 30 m length; 0.25 µm film thickness with a polyethylene glycol stationary phase). Briefly, the liquid products (ca. 50 mg) were diluted in 1.0 mL ethyl acetate with an internal standard of 10 mg dodecane. The 1.0 µL obtained mixture was then injected into the GC column at 250 °C. The oven temperature was programmed as follows: an initial isothermal hold at 50 °C for 3 min, ramp at 5 °C min–1 to 150 °C, hold for 10 min, then ramp at 10 °C min–1 to 300 °C, hold for 25 min. The evaluation was carried out in the split-split mode at the split ratio of 100:1 and He was used as the carrier gas (flow rate = 3 mL min–1). The selectivity to the product species was calculated from the percentage of the relative peak area obtained from the GC-MS chromatograms. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the nMgO-VKIT-6 and xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts. Before combining KIT-6 with vanadium or MgO, the KIT-6 displayed a typical IUPAC type IV isotherm. The sharp capillary condensation step and an H1 hysteresis loop appeared at the high relative pressure (P/Po) indicated the distribution of large channel like-pores and narrow pore sizes. The nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts containing different molar ratios of Mg/V (0.00–1.50) showed a type IV isotherm with an H4 hysteresis loop, indicating a narrow slit-shaped mesopore [26]. Whereas, the isotherms of the xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts having VxOy contents in the range of 0–9 wt% were similar to that of the pure mesoporous silicate KIT-6 sample. All isotherms displayed a type IV isotherm with an H1 hysteresis loop at the high P/Po in the range of 0.6–0.8, which was indicative to the mesoporous structure [27]. Textural properties (SBET, pore volume, and pore size) of the nMgO-VKIT-6 and xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts are presented in Table 1. The nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts exhibited a relatively large SBET in the range of 715–857 m2 g–1 and substantially high pore volumes at around in the range of 0.86–0.93 cm3 g–1. There was no continuous trend between the Mg/V molar ratios and the resultant SBET, but the addition of MgO into the VKIT-6 framework decreased the SBET when the Mg/V molar ratio was increased. The pore volumes increased from 0.86 to 0.93 cm3 g–1 as the Mg/V molar ratios increased from 0.00 to 1.50, suggesting MgO incorporation into the VKIT-6 framework. In addition, the increased pore volume was accompanied by an enlarged pore size from 3.85 to 4.27 nm when the Mg/V molar ratio was increased from 0.00 to 1.50. This was explained as being due to the substitution of Mg atoms into the framework of silica. Since the atomic radius of the Mg atom (1.45 Å) is greater than that of the Si atom (1.11 Å), the Mg atom possibly occupied the original position of the Si atom in the KIT-6 framework through the formation of Mg-O-Si bonds. This bond length is longer than that of the Si-O-Si bond, leading to a significant pore expansion [27]. As for the xV/MgO-KIT6 catalysts, the MgO-KIT-6 showed a high SBET (1001 m2 g–1) and exhibited a large pore diameter (5.23 nm), and pore volume (1.33 cm3 g–1). Comparatively, the SBET and pore volume of the xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts remarkably declined with increasing VxOy loadings, suggesting that the VxOy species localized on the MgO-KIT-6 surfaces and were encapsulated in the channels of the MgO-KIT-6 support. Nevertheless, the highest VxOy loading (9 V/MgO-KIT-6 catalyst) still achieved a respectable SBET of 317 m2 g–1 and pore volume of 0.47 cm3 g–1. It was also observed that the pore size of the xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts decreased from 5.23 nm to 4.94 nm when the VxOy loadings were below 5.0 wt%. Above this point, the pore sizes increased to 5.61–5.76 nm when the VxOy loading was increased, especially to 7.0 and 9.0 wt% (Table 1). Here, the small amount of VxOy loading induced the small VxOy particles to be homogeneously dispersed and deposited in the pores of the catalysts resulting in the smaller pore size and pore volume of the prepared catalysts. For the xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts containing a VxOy loading of ≥ 5 wt%, the pore size of the catalysts was larger (5.11–5.76 nm) with a lower pore volume (0.47–0.67 cm3 g–1). It was possible that the high VxOy level promoted the formation of VxOy agglomerates and that were partially deposited at the outer catalyst surface to form the interparticle channels with a larger pore size. Figs. 2a,b show the XRD patterns at small angles for the nMgO-VKIT-6 and xV/MgO-KIT-6 samples, respectively. It was observed that two well-resolved diffraction peaks of (211) and (332) at low diffraction angles, resembling the cubic Ia3d symmetry of mesoporous structures, were evident and similar to those of KIT-6 [27,28]. As for the nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts (Fig. 2a), the intensity of the diffraction peak (211) declined gradually as the Mg/V molar ratios were increased from 0.00 to 1.50, indicating the worse long-range ordering of the materials. Whereas, the diffraction peak (322) increased and became broader as the Mg/V molar ratios were increased from 0.00 to 0.50, suggesting that the extra pore structures were generated. This is accord with the increased pore size and pore volume depicted in Table 1. This diffraction peak was decreased with further increasing the Mg/V molar ratio at 1.50, suggesting that the higher MgO content caused some distortions in the long-range order of the mesoporous materials. In the case of the xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts (Fig. 2b), the intensity of the diffraction peak (211) increased at 3.0 wt% VxOy loading compared to that of the pure MgO-KIT-6. However, this peak intensity decreased and slightly shifted to lower angles when the loading of VxOy was over 3.0 wt%, which reflected the blockage of pores and the loss of the long-range order of the structure. The wide-angle XRD patterns of the nMgO-VKIT-6 and xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts are presented in Figs. 2c and 2d, respectively. All catalyst samples showed a broad peak at a 2θ of ca. 23°, ascribed to the amorphous SiO2 in the KIT-6 [27]. As for the nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts (Fig. 2c), the VKIT-6 sample showed the diffraction peaks at a 2θ of 15.5, 20, 22, 26, and 31°, which were attributed to the V2O5 crystallites [18]. These diffraction peaks began vanishing as increasing level of MgO were introduced. This result suggested that the presence of MgO with its intrinsic basic characteristics promoted the VxOy-MgO interaction and the incorporation of VxOy into the silica framework, and so preventing VxOy agglomeration. Note that only the 1.50MgO-VKIT-6 catalyst showed a MgO diffraction peak at a 2θ of 42° from the accumulation of polymeric MgO species [23]. To consider the xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts (Fig. 2d), the loading of VxOy on MgO-KIT-6 did not show any diffraction peaks corresponding to the crystalline V2O5, although the higher VxOy content decreased the SBET value of the obtained xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts. This implies that the incorporation of MgO into the framework of KIT-6 structure promoted a better VxOy species dispersion during the impregnation of the vanadium precursor. Although there were no diffraction peaks corresponding to magnesium vanadates over the xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts, the XRD results do not exclude the possibility of magnesium vanadates. According to Chaar et al. [29] magnesium vanadates can only be discovered over VMgO catalysts at a high vanadium content (> 24 wt%). The TEM images of the selected catalysts (VKIT-6, 0.50MgO-VKIT-6, MgO-KIT-6, and 3 V/MgO-KIT-6) are shown in Fig. 3. It was clearly seen that the VKIT-6 sample exhibited the well-ordered mesoporous structure (Fig. 3a), reflecting a typical KIT-6 morphology. This mesopore structure was retained after the introduction of MgO into the 0.50MgO-VKIT-6 catalyst (Fig. 3b). No VxOy and MgO particles could be observed on 0.50MgO-VKIT-6 mesoporous material, indicating that a homogeneous dispersion of VxOy and MgO was achieved via the direct hydrothermal method. The ordered pore channel was also observed in the MgO-KIT-6 catalyst (Fig. 3c). Although the 3V/MgO-KIT6 showed a similar mesoporous structure to pure MgO-KIT-6, the mouths of some mesopores were seen to be blocked by the black VxOy particles (Fig. 3d), which would cause the observed decline in the surface area (Table 1). Fig. 4 shows the H2-TPR profiles of the nMgO-VKIT-6 and xV/ MgO-KIT-6. As for the nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts, the VKIT-6 sample showed two reduction peaks at ca. 590 and 675 °C, respectively (Fig. 4a). The first peak was attributed to the reduction of well-dispersed tetrahedral vanadium species, while the second one was ascribed to the reduction of surface VxOy species with an unsaturated coordination [23,30]. As increasing the Mg/V molar ratios, the intensity of the first reduction peak declined and shifted to a lower temperature region of 590–560 °C. This implied that the incorporation of MgO into the VKIT-6 framework enhanced the reducibility of these catalysts. Whereas, the second reduction peak weakened in peak intensity, and began to vanish at a Mg/V molar ratio of 0.50. This was possibly due to the dispersion effect of MgO or to the formation of well-dispersed Mg-vanadate [23]. For xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts, their H2-TPR profiles (Fig. 4b) displayed single reduction peak centered at ca. 560–590 °C, corresponding to the reduction of well-dispersed tetrahedral vanadium species. Only one reduction peak was observed even at a high VxOy content loading (ca. 9 wt%), suggesting that the presence of MgO in the KIT-6 framework enhanced the dispersion of VxOy species and promoted a higher interaction between VxOy and MgO species [23]. With increasing vanadium loading levels, the reduction peaks intensity remarkably increased and gradually shifted to a higher temperature in the region of 560–595 °C. The NH3-TPD profiles of the nMgO-VKIT-6 and xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts were exhibited in Fig. S2. The NH3-TPD profiles of the nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts (Fig. S2a) showed the similar shape of desorption peaks at ca. 150 °C, attributed to the weak acid sites generated from the isolated tetrahedral-like coordinated VxOy species. The desorption peak at ca. 200 °C was ascribed to the medium acid sites. The increase in the Mg/V molar ratios decreased the intensity of the desorption peak of the weak acid sites, indicating a decline in the number of weak acid sites. Moreover, the 0.50MgO-VKIT-6 catalyst began to lose the medium acid desorption peak due to elimination of acidic surface sites. It was inferred that MgO species might incorporate both VxOy species and the Si–OH groups on the silicate framework. The total acidity obtained from the entire desorption peaks area declined from 96 to NH3-μmol g-1 when the Mg/V molar ratios increased from 0.00 to 1.50 (Table 1). For the NH3-TPD profiles of the xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts, Fig. S2b showed a single desorption peak appeared in the range of 100–200 °C ascribing to the weak acid sites obtained from the isolated tetrahedral-like coordinated VxOy species. As the VxOy loading increased, the intensity of these desorption peaks was greater and also shifted to the higher temperature region, indicating an increase in the number of weak acid sites. Moreover, the 9 V/MgO-KIT-6 catalyst, which had the highest VxOy loading, revealed a new stronger acidity site, which was reflected by the presence of a desorption peak at ca. 210 °C. The total acidity also increased from 70 to 400 NH3-µmol g–1 when the VxOy loading was increased from 1 to 9 wt%. (Table 1). Raman spectroscopy was further examined to understand the structural characterization of vanadium oxide species. The Raman spectra of the representative catalysts (KIT-6, MgO-KIT-6, 0.50MgO-VKIT-6, and 3 V/MgO-KIT-6) are presented in Fig. 5. The characteristic peaks at ca. 972 cm−1 (Si–OH), 810 cm−1 (Si–O–Si), 606 cm−1 (three-membered Si–O rings), and 487 cm−1 (four-membered Si–O rings) were assigned to the KIT-6 framework [31]. The vanadium-containing catalysts (0.50MgO-VKIT-6 and 3 V/MgO-KIT-6) exhibited a new peak at ca. 1036 cm−1 attributed to the vanadyl bond (VO) stretching vibration of isolated monomeric VO4 3– species [18,32]. Besides, characteristic peaks at ca. 994 cm–1 (symmetric VO stretching), 702, 527, 404 cm–1 (V–O–V stretching), and 284 cm–1 (V–O–V bending) assigning to V2O5 crystallites [33,34] were not observed for the vanadium-containing catalysts. This is consistent with the result observation in the wide-angle XRD spectra. In addition, the characteristic peak at 972 cm−1 corresponding to the surface silanol groups significantly decreased for the vanadium-containing catalysts, indicating the interaction of vanadium species with the surface silanol on the KIT-6 framework [27]. These results suggested that the vanadium species on the vanadium-containing catalysts existed in a highly dispersed and isolated environment without aggregating to form V2O5 crystallites. The surface chemical state of the selected catalysts (0.50MgO-VKIT-6 and 3V/MgO-KIT-6) was examined by XPS analysis ( Fig. 6). The BE of all the samples was corrected by reference to the C1s peak at 284.6 eV. The V2p XPS spectra of both catalysts exhibited a single peak centered at ca. 516.0–516.6 eV, which was assigned to the V3+ oxidation state (Fig. 6a) [35]. The peak centered at ca. 517.0 eV, attributed to V5+ in the form of V2O5 [36] was not observed. This indicated that the most of the vanadium was present in the V3+ oxidation state. Notably, the BE value of V2p on 3 V/MgO-KIT-6 (516.6 eV) was higher than that of 0.50MgO-VKIT-6 (516.0 eV), which was probably attributed to the formation of Mg-vanadates [23]. The Si2p spectra of both catalysts were deconvoluted into two Gaussian curves, as shown in Fig. 6b. The first peak at the higher BE of ca. 103.0 eV was assigned to the Si–O–Si bonds from silica, while the second peak at the lower BE of ca. 101.6 eV was attributed to the Si–O–Mg chemical bonds from the interaction of MgO and silicates [37]. The XPS spectra of O1s in both catalysts showed a sharp peak at ca. 531.0 eV (Fig. 6c) without any sidebands in the lower BE region corresponding to VxOy species [38]. This suggested that most of the loaded VxOy species were either incorporated into the KIT-6 framework or located inside the channels of the catalysts. The characterization of the catalysts was further determined using FTIR spectroscopy, as described in Fig. S3. The more explanation was also given in the supporting materials. 3.2 Oxidative dehydrogenation of oleic acid 3.2.1 Reaction pathway for the ODH of OA Scheme 2 delineates the postulated reaction pathways for the ODH of OA. Pathway (1) was conducted via direct decarboxylation (DCO2) of OA on the active sites. The C–C bonds at the α-position of –COOH group and the β-position of CC bonds in the OA structure were broken to generate the short-chain hydrocarbons and released CO2. Meanwhile, pathway (2) occurred via decarbonylation (DCO) of ketenes and aldehydes molecules, which were obtained from the reduction and dehydration of OA. The C−C bond was cleaved at the α- and β-positions of CC bonds to create short-chain hydrocarbons and CO. Besides, pathway (3) took place through the oxidative cleavage of the CC bond in the OA. Consequently, a carboxylic acid and an aldehyde were formed. These subjects underwent the DCO2 and dehydration processes to generate alkanes and alkenes, respectively. Additionally, aromatics were possibly generated from a sequence of reactions, involving oligomerization, cyclization, and aromatization, of the formed alkenes and dienes in any of the given reaction routes [36]. The aromatics could then further undergo polymerization to produce polyaromatics. The reaction mechanism for the ODH of OA over vanadium-KIT-6 catalysts has been proposed previously [22]. 3.2.2 Catalytic performance Based on the results from the previous study [22], the ODH of OA over the nMgO-VKIT-6 and xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts was conducted at 450 °C under atmosphere using 0.25 g catalyst content with a constant OA feed rate of 0.089 g min–1 and O2/N2 (1/1 (v/v)) flow rate of 100 mL min−1. The ODH of OA produced predominantly gas and liquid, with only a trace amount of solid (coke). The gas products were consisted of (i) light alkanes (C1–4) such as CH4, C2H6, C3H8, i-C4H10, and n-C4H10; and (ii) light olefins (C= 2–4), such as C2H4, C3H6, C3H4, and C4H8; and (iii) combustion products (CO and CO2). Some other gaseous compounds, such as iso-pentane and n-pentane, were likely generated, but they could not to be determined by using the present standard gas. A range of HCs, consisting of C7–17 in the forms of oxygenates, cyclics, aromatics, alkanes, and alkenes, was present in the liquid products. The oxygenates included carboxylic acids, alcohol, ketones, aldehydes, and esters. Table 2 displays the conversion of OA and product distribution generated from the ODH of OA catalyzed by nMgO-VKIT-6 and xV/MgO-KIT-6. For the nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts, the ODH of OA over VKIT-6 showed an OA conversion of 76.3%. Under similar conditions, the conversion of OA was negligible in the absence of a catalyst, which indicated that thermal decomposition played an insignificant role in the observed activity. The presence of MgO had a marked effect on the conversion of OA, where the degree of OA conversion was strongly increased from 76% to 95.5% as the Mg/V molar ratios were increased from 0 to 0.50 (Table 2). This was attributed to the higher dispersion of vanadyl species on the framework in the presence of MgO, which then resulted in the well-dispersed isolated tetrahedral species that could promote the ODH process. However, the OA conversion level was reduced to 85.2% when the Mg/V molar ratio was above 0.50 (Table 2), probably due to the accumulation of MgO (Fig. 2c). The product distribution was also strongly depended on the Mg/V molar ratios in the catalyst. The gas products declined from 28.2 to 23.8 wt%, while the liquid products increased from 71.7 to 76.2 wt% with the rise of Mg/V molar ratio from 0.00 to 1.50 (Table 2). This was due to the effect of high dispersion of tetrahedral VxOy species in the catalysts, which possessed a low tendency to generate cracking products. Moreover, the lower catalyst acidity (as the Mg/V molar ratio increased) also decreased the potential for further secondary cracking of the liquid products. For xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts, the degree of OA conversion with the MgO-KIT-6 catalyst without vanadium was only 62.5%. The enhancement of the VxOy contents from 0 to 3 wt% resulted in a greater OA conversion level to 91.1% (Table 2), which was possibly due to the well-dispersed vanadium species (tetrahedral VO4) on the MgO-KIT-6 framework. However, the higher VxOy contents above 3 wt% strongly decreased the SBET and pore volume (Table 1). Consequently, the OA conversion level started to decrease (Table 2). In addition, the product distribution was also influenced by the VxOy contents, where the gas product decreased from 29.5 to 24.3 wt% and the liquid product correspondingly increased from 70.2 to 75.7 wt% as the VxOy content increased from 0 to 5 wt% (Table 2). This was presumably due to the good dispersion of vanadium into the MgO-KIT-6 framework resulting in the formation vanadium-magnesium, which inhibited the cracking process to produce small HCs. However, the amount of gas product increased with decreasing the liquid yield when the VxOy loading was further increased to 9 wt%. This was due to the higher catalyst acidity (Table 1) to promote the secondary cracking of the liquid phase. Interestingly, the solid product, defined as the coke formed on the surface of the catalysts during the ODH of OA, was clearly minimal. It implied that the negligible coke was generated from this process, demonstrating the benefits of the ODH process in the production of olefins from OA. In order to elucidate the participation of oxygen in the ODH of OA, the reaction was comparatively conducted in the present of N2 gas under a typical condition using 1 V/MgO-KIT-6 catalyst at the same total flow rate of 100 mL min−1 as used in the ODH process. It was observed that only 1% OA conversion was observed. The trace amounts of the C17 = olefin and oxygenated compounds (C18+) were formed most likely due to the coupling of alkyl radicals (Table S1). Generally, the system operated under high reaction temperature and inert atmosphere is called as “pyrolysis”. Although the system was operated under high temperature (450 ⁰C), the short contact time at ca. 2.8 min (calculated from the ratio of catalyst (ca. 0.25 g) content and OA feed rate (0.089 g min–1)) might be insufficient to convert OA. Moreover, it was possible that the vanadium-based catalysts with vanadium oxide as the main component were effective for almost all oxidation reactions [39], not for pyrolysis process. As a result, the lack of oxygen ions in the system performed under oxygen-free atmosphere could not abstract the hydrogen atom in the OA structure. This result suggested that the molecular oxygen plays an important role by acting as the agent for promoting the ODH reaction and recycling the catalyst via oxidation to form the active VO4 3– again [40]. Molecular oxygen was an initial resources oxygen ions for the activation of free radicals in the ODH of OA. According to the stated mechanism, the hydrogen atom from the 16th carbon of OA was firstly adsorbed on the active sites of the catalyst [41], which was then abstracted by oxygen ions producing OH groups, CO2 and C17 = olefin. When the OH groups formed were removed from the catalyst’s surface by dehydration, the catalyst must be subsequently re-oxidized by oxygen in the gas phase as shown in Scheme 3. Although the ODH of light alkanes (propane) under oxygen-free atmosphere have been reported over catalyst lattice oxygen such as vanadium-based catalysts [40,42,43], the propane conversion (2–3%) was much lower than those carried out under molecular oxygen, but its selectivity toward propylene was higher (88.3–94.8%). It was suggested that the reaction without the assistance of molecular oxygen seems to be inappropriate for the larger molecules like OA under these conditions using vanadium-based catalysts. Fig. 7a shows the selectivity of species found in the liquid products generated from the ODH of OA over nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts having various Mg/V molar ratios. Besides OA conversion, the selectivity to the corresponding products is also a vital factor in determining the effectiveness of a catalyst in the ODH of OA. The results showed that the nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts exhibited a slightly higher alkenes selectivity than that of VKIT-6, indicating the beneficial effect of MgO on the ODH of OA. The selectivity toward alkenes gradually increased accompanied by reduced levels of oxygenates when the Mg/V molar ratios were in the range of 0.00–0.50. The highest alkenes selectivity at 40% with a correspondingly lowest oxygenates level at 13% was achieved with the 0.50MgO-VKIT-6 catalyst. This was due to the formation of highly dispersed and isolated (tetrahedral) VxOy species, which were considered as the active and selective sites for the ODH of OA. Because the OA molecules could be adsorbed on the catalyst surface, they were then activated by the highly reactive surface oxygen species in the isolated VxOy species. A hydrogen atom in a HC molecule was abstracted to create an adsorbed alkyl radical and a surface OH group [19]. Moreover, the lower acidity catalysts (as the Mg/V molar ratio increased) were favorable for the rapid desorption of the formed alkenes and dienes from the catalyst surface, which restricted their further deep oxidation to form oxygenates. A similar phenomenon was previously observed in the ODH of octane over VMgO catalysts [21,44]. However, the selectivity to alkenes was reduced in tandem with the rising level of oxygenates content when the Mg/V molar ratio was over 0.5. In addition, the selectivity toward dienes gradually increased from 6.8% to 12%, whereas the selectivity to aromatics and alkanes declined from 24% to 16.5% and from 9.4% to 6.7%, respectively, when the Mg/V molar ratio increased from 0.00 to 1.50. As the Mg/V molar ratio increased, the total acidity was dropped (Table 1). This decreased acidity likely enhanced the desorption of the formed dienes from the catalyst surface, and so minimized the chances for further reactions, such as cyclization and aromatization, to consequently generate the aromatics. The trend for aromatics selectivity was opposite to that of the dienes, suggesting that dienes were probably precursors of aromatics. The amount of gas products such as light olefins (C= 2–4) and alkanes (C1–4) declined from 2.81 to 2.15 mol% and from 2.02 to 1.33 mol%, respectively, when the Mg/V molar ratios increased from 0.00 to 1.50 (Table S2). This was most likely due to the decreased acidity, which could prevent further secondary cracking reactions of the liquid products. On the other hand, the presence of MgO influenced the α-alkenes/total alkenes ratio, which slightly increased from 0.59 to 0.62 as the Mg/V molar ratio was increased. This might be related to the acid–base characteristics of the catalysts. The lower acidity would decrease the cleavage of the formed α-olefins at the β-position of the CC bond, a cleavage that produced an alkane and light alkene, resulting in a reduction in the proportion of α-alkenes. Consistent with this is that the light olefins (C= 2–4) content (Table S2) and alkane selectivity (Fig. 7a) were also reduced with increasing Mg/V molar ratios. Moreover, the lower acidity was likely to lead a quick desorption of the generated alkenes on the catalyst surface, and so decreased the chance for further transformation of alkenes, particularly in the high active α-alkenes. As a result, α-alkenes/total alkenes ratio was higher. Fig. 7b shows the selectivity to components in the liquid products derived from the ODH of OA using the xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts with different VxOy contents. The selectivity towards alkenes and oxygenates generated from the system using a MgO-KIT-6 catalyst without vanadium was 31% and 19%, respectively. The 1 V/MgO-KIT-6 catalyst showed the highest selectivity for alkenes at 39.5% with the lowest selectivity to oxygenated compounds at 13.4%. This was possibly due to the high distribution of isolated VxOy species in the MgO-KIT-6 at a low VxOy loading, which would promote the ODH process rather than deep oxidation. However, the selectivity toward alkenes and aromatics gradually dropped from 39.5% to 29% and from 19.1% to 10.5%, respectively, whereas the oxygenated compounds increased from 13.4% to 36.0%, as the VxOy level increased from 1 to 9 wt%. This was due to the formation of polymeric VxOy species, which are more favorable towards deep oxidation than the ODH process [16,21]. These polymeric VxOy species exist inside the catalysts channels as demonstrated by the lower total pore volume as the VxOy loading level increased (Table 1). Moreover, catalysts with a higher acidic content (increased VxOy content) possibly hindered the desorption of the formed products from the catalyst surface, which provided more chances for further oxidation to generate oxygenated compounds. Fig. 8 displays the carbon atom distribution in the liquid products obtained from the reaction using nMgO-VKIT-6 and xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts. The compositions of the olefins were divided into three categories, depending on their prospective applications: C= 5–9 (co-monomers for polymerization), C= 10–14 (detergent precursors), and C= 15–17 (surfactant and oilfield fluids). The primary alkenes formed were in the C10–14 and C15–17 product ranges, whilst the larger C18+ molecules were aromatics and oxygenates. For the nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts, the presence of MgO with Mg/V molar ratios of 0.00–0.50 remarkably reduced the formation of C18 + oxygenates by promoting the generation of alkenes in the C10–14 and C15–17 ranges (Fig. 8a). In addition, the yield of dienes increased while the aromatics showed the opposite trend to that of dienes in the C10–17 range. However, the formation of C18+ aromatics and oxygenates was increased when the 1.50MgO-VKIT-6 catalyst was applied. This was presumably due to the existence of polymeric MgO species at high Mg/V molar ratio, which enhanced the formation of oxygenated compounds. The VxOy content also affected the carbon atoms distribution in the liquid products generated from the ODH of OA using xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts (Fig. 8b). The MgO-KIT-6 catalyst without vanadium showed an oxygenated compound content in the range of C5–17 and C18+ structures. The oxygenates decreased in the C5–17 range, but slightly rose in the C18+ structure, and C18+ aromatics appeared when VxOy was introduced at 1 wt%. However, the aromatics in the C10–17 range and C18+ structure declined and correspondingly the proportion of oxygenated compounds increased when the VxOy contents increased from 1 to 9 wt%. This implied that the aromatics were further oxidized to form the corresponding oxygenated compounds. 3.3 Kinetic study of the reaction The kinetic study was performed based on the optimal experiments using the 1 V/MgO-KIT-6 catalyst at 450 ⁰C with different OA feed rates in the range of 0.053–0.107 g min–1. The OA conversion and representative products selectivity profiles as a function of the contact time obtained from the ratio of catalyst content/OA feed rate are shown in Fig. 9. It was observed that the conversion of OA increased with increasing the contact time. Furthermore, the longer contact time decreased the alkenes selectivity in tandem with increasing in the level of oxygenated compounds formation. This indicated that the longer contact time could enhance the further undesirable reactions such as cracking or deep oxidation of the formed alkenes, thereby increasing the formation of oxygenated species. Besides, the increase in the contact time gradually dropped the selectivity toward dienes, while the selectivity toward aromatics increased. This revealed that increasing contact time was likely to enhance the chances for further reactions like cyclization and aromatization to consequently produce the aromatics. The reverse relation between dienes and aromatics selectivity implied that dienes were precursors to produce aromatics. 3.4 TGA analysis of the spent catalysts In order to examine the coke formed on the catalyst’s surface, TGA under air atmosphere was performed for the spent nMgO-VKIT-6 and xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts after 2 h time on stream at 450 °C. Fig. 10 showed the TGA (inset DTG) profiles of the spent catalysts obtained from the ODH of OA. Generally, the mass loss of the spent catalyst was due to the removal of carbon deposited on the catalyst’s surface. The coke formed on the surface of all spent catalysts was mostly soft coke, which was corresponded to the peak at 200–600 °C in the DTG curves (inset Figs. 10a and 10b) [45]. The amount of coke was determined from the mass loss between 300 and 800 °C in the TGA curves. For the nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts, the amount of coke formed on the VKIT-6 surface was 5.2 wt%. The presence of MgO strongly affected the coke formation on the spent nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts, decreasing the coke content to 0.7–1.3 wt% when the Mg/V molar ratio was applied in the studied range (Fig. 10a, Table S3). The VxOy contents also influenced the amount of coke formation on the spent xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts (Fig. 10b), where the spent MgO-KIT-6 showed 8.2 wt% coke that strongly declined with increasing VxOy contents to a negligible level (less than 1 wt%) at a high vanadium loading (Fig. 10b, Table S3). The uniform channel with the large pore size of the catalysts probably made them easy to release the generated products to the outer of the pore [46], which was crucial for preventing coke formation and minimizing the coke deposition during the ODH of OA. 4 Conclusions The nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts with different Mg/V molar ratios (n = 0.00–1.50), and xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts with different VxOy contents (x = 0–9 wt%) were successfully prepared and used to produce long-chain bio-olefins via the ODH of OA. The NH3-TPD and H2-TPR results indicated that the Mg/V molar ratios and VxOy contents strongly influenced the acid-base characteristics and reducibility of the catalysts. An increased Mg/V molar ratio decreased the catalyst acidity, but increased the reducibility of the nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts. On the other hand, the higher acidity with lower reducibility of the catalysts was obtained as the vanadium content increased in the xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts. These catalysts showed a good selectivity toward olefins (alkene + dienes) of 52% at a relatively high OA conversion level of 88–95%. The selectivity towards the desired products depended on the acid-base characteristics of the catalyst as well as the highly dispersed isolated VxOy species in the catalyst framework. Both the 0.50MgO-VKIT-6 catalyst prepared by the direct hydrothermal method and the 1 V/MgO-KIT-6 catalyst prepared by the impregnation method showed the highest catalytic performance with an olefin (alkene + dienes) and aromatic selectivity of up to 52% and 20%, respectively, with the lowest oxygenates level (13%) when the ODH of OA was conducted using a GHSV of 400 [mL/(min g–cat)] at 450 °C. coredata.dc:description: This study investigated the effect of magnesium oxide (MgO) incorporation into vanadium-KIT-6 (VKIT-6) catalysts and vanadium oxide (VxOy) contents impregnated into MgO-KIT-6 catalysts on the catalytic activity in the oxidative dehydrogenation of oleic acid to generate long-chain bio-olefins ( ≥ C10). The nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts containing different Mg/V molar ratios (n = 0.00–1.50) were prepared by the hydrothermal process, while xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts were synthesized via wet-impregnation method with different vanadium contents (x = 0–9 wt%). The Mg/V molar ratios in the nMgO-VKIT-6 catalysts and VxOy contents in the xV/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts strongly affected the catalytic performance and selectivity to the desired products. Both 0.50MgO-VKIT-6 and 1 V/MgO-KIT-6 catalysts showed the best catalytic activity for the desired products with selectivity to olefins (alkenes + dienes) and aromatics of 52% and 20%, respectively. The high selective production to the desired products was ascribed to the highly dispersed and isolated VxOy species on the catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Vanadium-magnesium oxides/KIT-6 catalysts for oxidative dehydrogenation of oleic acid to long-chain bio-olefins
